questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for her routine Pap smear. The physician obtains a Pap smear and sends it to the lab. The results show dysplasia in the cells of the transformational zone. Which of the following is true about dysplasia?

choices.text: Dysplasia can be reversible if the inciting factor is removed.
Dysplasia is a true adaptive process.
Dysplastic cells have lower nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio than normal cells.
Dysplasia involves invasion of the basement membrane.
Dysplasia always progresses to cancer even if the inciting factor is removed.

questions.solution:
Dysplasia is a pathological transformation characterized by abnormal growth of cells in the tissue. It usually occurs due to a mutation in one of the cells and can occur spontaneously or develop on top of hyperplasia or metaplasia. Hyperplasia and metaplasia are considered to be risk factors for dysplasia. For example, human papillomavirus infection of the cervix can lead to dysplasia without hyperplasia or metaplasia. On the other hand, Barrett esophagus is a metaplastic process that can progress to dysplasia, and endometrial hyperplasia can also progress to metaplasia.  

Dysplasia is not considered a true adaptive process and dysplastic cells have characteristic features which can distinguish them from normal cells. These features include:  

  • Cellular pleomorphism: which means that cells have unequal sizes  
  • Nuclear pleomorphism: which means that the nuclei of the cells in the tissue have different sizes and shapes  
  • Hyperchromatism: because of the rapid division of dysplastic cells, these cells have abundant chromatin, which gives their nuclei a darker appearance.  
  • Increased number of mitotic cells: also because these cells have rapid division, the number of cells with mitotic figures increases.

Dysplasia is a precancerous state; however, if the inciting event is removed, dysplasia can be reversed. On the other hand, if the inciting event is not removed, dysplasia can progress to neoplasia (e.g., carcinoma in situ, invasive carcinoma) which is irreversible.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Dysplasia can be reversible if the inciting factor is removed.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dysplasia is a true adaptive process.:
Incorrect: Dysplasia is not considered a true adaptive process, unlike hyperplasia and metaplasia.  
❌ Dysplastic cells have lower nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio than normal cells.  :
Incorrect: Dysplastic cells are characterized by increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios, due to increased gene expression in these rapidly dividing cells.  
❌ Dysplasia involves invasion of the basement membrane.:
Incorrect: Neoplasia is characterized by invasion of the basement membrane, whereas dysplasia is not.  
❌ Dysplasia always progresses to cancer even if the inciting factor is removed.:
Incorrect: Dysplasia can be reversed sometimes if the inciting factor is removed.

questions.text: A study was conducted on patients with type II diabetes mellitus. In the study, it was shown that the majority of patients develop insulin deficiency after 10+ years of the diagnosis. Microscopic examination of the Islets of Langerhans from an affected patient reveals the destruction of the beta cells and deposition of a material that stains red on Congo stain. Which of the following was the most likely cause of pancreatic beta cell damage in these patients?

choices.text: Inflammation due to deposition of amylin in the islets of Langerhans
Inflammation due to immune complex deposition in the islets of Langerhans
Inflammation due to deposition of AL amyloid in the islets of Langerhans
Inflammation due to deposition of wild-type transthyretin

questions.solution:
Localized amyloidosis occurs when amyloid deposits in a single organ, leading to organ damage. Some well-known examples include:  

  • Alzheimer disease: in Alzheimer disease, a protein called amyloid polypeptide (APP) is cleaved and misfolded into amyloid known as β-amyloid protein, which deposits in the brain, causing damage. β-amyloid protein deposits around nerves impair nerve conduction in the brain's nerves and the walls of the blood vessels in the brain, causing the weakening of these walls and increasing the propensity for rupture and hemorrhage. Finally, the widespread deposition of amyloid in the brain causes inflammation which results in the declining function of the brain.  
  • Senile cardiac amyloidosis: In this condition, normal transthyretin (TTR) gradually and slowly misfolds and deposits in the heart's walls leading to cardiomyopathy. This is usually seen in elderly patients as this process takes a prolonged time.  
  • Diabetes mellitus type II: in DM II, islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) deposits in the islets of Langerhans, damaging the cells. This is why patients with long-standing DM II eventually develop insulin deficiency from damaged cells in the islets of Langerhans.  

Other diseases that can lead to localized amyloidosis include medullary thyroid cancer (calcitonin deposition) and isolated atrial amyloidosis (atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) deposition).  



Option Analysis

✅ Inflammation due to deposition of amylin in the islets of Langerhans  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inflammation due to immune complex deposition in the islets of Langerhans  :
Incorrect: Beta cell destruction in diabetes mellitus type II patients results from inflammation secondary to amylin deposition.  
❌ Autoimmune destruction  :
Incorrect: Autoimmune destruction of the beta cells is seen in type I DM, not type II DM.  
❌ Inflammation due to deposition of AL amyloid in the islets of Langerhans  :
Incorrect: Inflammation due to the deposition of AL amyloid in the islets of Langerhans can cause DM type II in patients with multiple myeloma. However, in DM type II, beta cells produce amylin that deposits in the islets of Langerhans, causing inflammation and beta cell destruction.  
❌ Inflammation due to deposition of wild-type transthyretin  :
Incorrect: Senile cardiac amyloidosis results from the heart's deposition of the normal (wild-type) transthyretin. It does not deposit in the islets of Langerhans.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient’s estimated blood loss is around 2 liters. A day later, she began experiencing crampy abdominal pain and multiple bloody bowel movements. Which of the following regions of the gastrointestinal tract is at the most significant risk for ischemia?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of ischemic colitis following a motor vehicle accident complicated by significant blood loss. Among the answer choices, the rectosigmoid junction is at the most critical risk of developing ischemia.  

Ischemia is the suppression or reduction of blood flow to an organ or tissue. The condition can arise due to decreased arterial perfusion (e.g., atherosclerosis, embolic stroke), impaired venous drainage (e.g., Budd-Chiari syndrome, testicular torsion), or shock.  

Watershed zones, which are areas of the body that receive dual blood supply from the most distal branches of two arteries, are highly vulnerable to ischemia in the setting of systemic hypoperfusion. By contrast, in cases of arterial occlusion (e.g. embolus obstructing one of the arteries), the watershed regions are spared mainly due to their dual blood supply. Examples of watershed regions include the intestinal splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction, as well as the boundary areas between the brain's anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries.  

In addition to watershed zones, other areas of the body susceptible to ischemia include the liver's and renal medulla's centrilobular zone (since both regions have poor oxygen supply and high metabolic demands) as well as the left ventricular subendocardium (since it can be perfused only during diastole).   

Option Analysis

❌ Stomach:
Incorrect: The stomach receives extensive blood supply from branches of the celiac artery. In the setting of hypovolemia, the stomach is less susceptible to ischemic injury than watershed regions that receive blood from the most distal branches of two arteries. Examples of watershed regions in the gastrointestinal tract include the splenic flexure of the large intestines and the rectosigmoid junction.  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The duodenum receives extensive blood supply from branches of the celiac artery and superior mesenteric artery. As a result, in the setting of hypovolemia, the duodenum is less susceptible to ischemia than watershed regions receiving blood from the most distal branches of two arteries. Examples of watershed regions in the gastrointestinal tract include the splenic flexure of the large intestines and the rectosigmoid junction.  
❌ Ileocecal junction  :
Incorrect: The ileocecal junction is where the small and large intestines meet. Branches of the superior mesenteric artery supply this region. In cases of hypovolemia, the ileocecal junction is less susceptible to ischemia than watershed regions that receive blood from the most distal branches of two arteries.  
❌ Descending colon:
Incorrect: The descending colon is supplied by branches of the inferior mesenteric artery. In cases of hypovolemia, the descending colon is less susceptible to ischemia than watershed regions that receive blood from the most distal branches of two arteries.  
✅ Rectosigmoid junction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is being examined for exercise intolerance. The patient develops severe shortness of breath 5 minutes after exercising. The patient also complains of knee pain that worsens throughout the day and improves with rest. Family history is significant for an uncle with ulcerative colitis. Echocardiography reveals a thickening of the walls of both ventricles. ECG reveals low-voltage electrical activity. A biopsy of the heart is taken and reveals infiltration of the walls of the ventricles by inclusion that has apple green color under polarized light. Which of the following has most likely resulted in this patient’s cardiac abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with restrictive cardiomyopathy, and the most likely cause is familial amyloid cardiomyopathy, a hereditary disorder caused by the deposition of mutant transthyretin amyloid.   

Transthyretin (TTR) is a protein that is produced in the liver. The normal (wild-type) form is the amyloid precursor protein that gets deposited in the heart of elderly patients and may lead to senile cardiac amyloidosis. On the other hand, the mutant form of transthyretin can lead to hereditary amyloidosis that can be seen in younger individuals.   

Two forms of hereditary amyloidosis have been identified, and the mutant form of TTR causes both. The mutant variant of TTR has increased amyloidogenesis potential.  

The first hereditary amyloidosis is familial amyloid cardiomyopathy, where the patient's symptoms are predominantly cardiac. The deposition of the mutant TTR amyloid causes restrictive/infiltrative cardiomyopathy, and the patient usually develops heart failure with conduction disturbances. The other form is familial amyloid polyneuropathies, where the mutated TTR amyloid deposits and damages peripheral nerves, including somatic and autonomic nerves.  

Hereditary amyloidosis due to mutations in TTR is usually autosomal dominant with variable penetrance. Patients usually present in their 30s to early 40s. Some patients may develop cardiac disorders, while others can develop neuropathies. However, some patients develop features of both.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in transthyretin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chronic rheumatoid arthritis  :
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis results in AA amyloidosis, systemic amyloidosis with features in multiple organs throughout the body. This patient’s young age and only cardiac manifestations suggest that he most likely has familial amyloid cardiomyopathy. Furthermore, the patient’s knee pain that worsens with activity is more characteristic of osteoarthritis.  
❌ Inflammatory bowel disorder  :
Incorrect: IBD can also cause AA amyloidosis, a systemic amyloidosis that is not localized like that seen in this patient.  
❌ Multiple myeloma  :
Incorrect: Multiple myeloma can lead to AL amyloidosis, which is systemic amyloidosis that involves the heart and other organs. However, multiple myeloma is unlikely in this patient, given his age and lack of symptoms related to multiple myeloma (e.g. back pain).  
❌ Age-related process  :
Incorrect: Senile amyloid cardiomyopathy results from the age-related deposition of normal (wild-type) transthyretin in the heart. However, this process is slow and seen in the elderly. This patient’s young age suggests familial amyloid cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of a tingling sensation in both hands. On physical examination, firm pressure on the carpal tunnel elicits the reproduction of the pain, characterized by paresthesias and pain. Nerve conduction study confirms carpal tunnel syndrome. The patient was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome six months ago, and one year ago, he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. A fat pad biopsy reveals depositions that have apple-green color under polarized light. The abnormal folding and deposition of which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Amyloidosis is a disease where misfolded proteins aggregate and deposit in tissues leading to organ damage. Amyloidosis is divided into systemic amyloidosis, where the deposits occur in many different organs around the body, or localized, where the abnormal proteins deposit in one organ only.  

Systemic amyloidosis is also divided into AL (primary) amyloidosis, AA (secondary) amyloidosis, and dialysis-related amyloidosis (β2-microglobulin).  

AL amyloidosis, also known as primary amyloidosis, is a systemic form of amyloidosis resulting from the deposition of misfolded immunoglobulin light chains (the ‘L’ in ‘AL’ refers to light chains) in various organs in the body. This is usually seen in multiple myeloma, where excessive production of Ig light chains results in the production of misfolded forms that leak into the blood and then deposit in organs leading to systemic amyloidosis.  

The second form of systemic amyloidosis is AA amyloidosis, also known as secondary amyloidosis.  AA amyloidosis is due to the deposition of misfolded serum amyloid A. Serum amyloid A is an acute phase reactant produced in states of inflammation. In diseases with chronic production of serum amyloid A, the production of misfolded forms that deposit in organs causing organ damage. AA amyloidosis is seen in chronic inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis (the most common cause of AA amyloidosis) and inflammatory bowel disease and can also be seen in some cancers.  

Dialysis-related amyloidosis is another form of systemic amyloidosis seen in patients on long-term dialysis. These patients have increased production of β2-microglobulin, which misfolds and deposits in various organs, causing amyloidosis.  

Systemic amyloidosis manifestations result from organ damage around the body caused by amyloid depositions. The most commonly involved organs in systemic amyloidosis include:  
  • The kidneys: amyloid damages the podocytes, leading to nephrotic syndrome  
  • The heart: amyloid deposition leads to stiffening of the walls of the ventricles causing restrictive cardiomyopathy, which may progress to heart failure. Also, it can lead to arrhythmias.  
  • The gastrointestinal system: leading to malabsorption (from damage to the villi by amyloid), and enlargement of the liver, spleen, and tongue.  
  • The nervous system: amyloid deposition can cause damage to the peripheral nervous system, including sensory and motor nerves, as well as the autonomic nervous system. 



Option Analysis

❌ Serum amyloid A  :
Incorrect: Serum amyloid A misfolding and deposition leads to AA amyloidosis, which is systemic amyloidosis seen in conditions of chronic inflammation. However, in multiple myeloma, AL amyloidosis occurs due to the deposition of misfolded light chains.  
❌ β2-microglobulin  :
Incorrect: β2-microglobulin is the type of amyloid seen in patients on dialysis.  
✅ Immunoglobulin light chains  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mutated transthyretin  :
Incorrect: Mutated transthyretin is a type of hereditary amyloidosis and can cause cardiomyopathy when deposited in the heart or polyneuropathies when deposited in the nerves. However, this patient most likely has AL amyloidosis, given his recent diagnosis of multiple myeloma.  
❌ β-amyloid protein  :
Incorrect: β-amyloid protein is a type of amyloidosis seen in Alzheimer patients. It is a form of localized amyloidosis where β-amyloid protein deposits in the brain.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of urine that has been “bubbly” and “frothy.”. Urinalysis reveals >4 g of protein in the urine over a 24-hour collection period. A biopsy was taken from the kidney and examined under a microscope. Histological examination reveals depositions in the mesangium, which appear red on Congo stain and have an apple-green color under polarized light. This stained inclusion is most likely made of which of the following?

choices.text: Oxidized proteins with carbohydrates and polymers lipids

questions.solution:
Amyloidosis is a disease characterized by the deposition of abnormally folded proteins (amyloid) in different tissues and organs. These misfolded proteins stick together in beta-sheets outside the cells, depositing in the extracellular space and leading to tissue damage. Amyloidosis is divided into systemic amyloidosis, where the deposits occur in many different organs around the body, or localized, where the abnormal proteins deposit in one organ only.  

When examined under microscopy, Congo red stain is used to identify amyloid. With Congo red stain, amyloid appears red under non-polarized light. Under polarized light, amyloid has apple-green birefringence, which is unique for amyloid.  


Option Analysis

✅ Misfolded protein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immune complexes  :
Incorrect: Immune complexes are antigens and antibodies that aggregate and deposit in different organs leading to organ damage (e.g. membranous nephropathy). However, apple green birefringence under polarized light is a feature of amyloid and is not seen in immune complexes.  
❌ Glycosaminoglycans:
Incorrect: Amyloid is made of misfolded proteins that aggregate in beta-sheets and deposit in various organs.  
❌ Calcium deposits  :
Incorrect: Calcium deposits in various body organs (calcifications) can be seen with an H&E stain, which appears dark blue. However, it would not have apple-green birefringence under polarized light.  
❌ Oxidized proteins with carbohydrates and polymers lipids  :
Incorrect: Lipofuscins are made up of oxidized proteins complex with lipids and phospholipids. It typically appears as granular deposits of brown pigment in macrophages. However, apple green birefringence under polarized light is a feature of amyloid.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for a follow-up appointment. He was recently diagnosed with hereditary hemochromatosis. The patient is informed that the liver cells of affected individuals are exposed to more free radical injury than those of healthy individuals. Which enzymes play a vital role in protecting cells from free radical injury?
questions.solution:
This patient has been diagnosed with hereditary hemochromatosis, characterized by iron overload. The excess iron generates free radicals that damage the body’s cells. Glutathione peroxidase can convert hydrogen peroxide (which can undergo free radical reactions) into harmless water.   Free radicals are molecules with an unpaired electron in their outer orbital. They may arise due to exposure to ionizing radiation, drugs (e.g. acetaminophen), metals, or inflammation. The free radicals can cause cellular damage via lipid peroxidation and DNA and protein oxidation.  

The body has three primary mechanisms via which it eliminates free radicals.  

  • The first involves antioxidants such as vitamin A, C, and E. Antioxidants donate electrons and protect cells from damage.  
  • The second mechanism involves scavenging enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase, catalase, and superoxide dismutase. These enzymes assist in the conversion of free radicals into harmless water.  
  • The final mechanism involves metal carrier proteins such as ferritin, which carries iron, and ceruloplasmin, which carries copper. These proteins chelate metal ions and, in turn, prevent free radical generation.  


Option Analysis

❌ Cytochrome c oxidase  :
Incorrect: Cytochrome c oxidase is found in the mitochondria and is part of the electron transport chain. It plays an essential role in oxidative phosphorylation, which can generate free radicals. In contrast, cytochrome c oxidase is not involved in protecting cells against free radical injury.  
❌ NADPH oxidase  :
Incorrect: NADPH oxidase is an essential enzyme in the oxidative burst reaction pathway. This enzyme is found in the lysosomes of phagocytes and helps generate free radicals. These free radicals combine with chloride to create hypochlorite (bleach), which can be used to kill invading pathogens.  
✅ Glutathione peroxidase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myeloperoxidase:
Incorrect: Myeloperoxidase is an enzyme that produces hypochlorous acid from hydrogen peroxide and chloride ions. This enzyme plays a vital role in the innate immune system and can be found in cells such as neutrophils and monocytes. However, myeloperoxidase does not play a role in protecting cells from free radical injury.
❌ Ferroportin:
Incorrect: Ferroportin is a transmembrane protein that transports iron out of cells and into the bloodstream. This protein is not directly involved in protecting cells against free radical injury. In contrast, proteins such as transferrin can chelate iron in the bloodstream and, in turn, reduce the amount of free radicals generated.

questions.text: A patient in the intensive care unit develops disseminated intravascular coagulation and passes away several days later. An autopsy is performed. Which of the following organs will most likely exhibit areas of red infarction?
questions.solution:
Infarction describes local tissue or organ death secondary to an inadequate blood supply. Areas of infarction can be divided into red and pale infarcts. These terms describe the gross appearance of the infarcted areas.  

Red infarcts can arise due to venous occlusions (e.g., ovarian torsion) or if blood re-enters and collects in infarcted areas. This finding will typically manifest in loosely organized organs with multiple blood supplies. Examples of such organs include the liver, lungs, intestines, and testis.  

The infarcts are frequently wedge-shaped, with the occluding vessel being the apex. In contrast, pale infarcts typically occur in solid organs with end-arterial circulation, such as the spleen, heart, kidneys, and retina. In such organs, the tissue density limits the seepage of blood from patent vascular beds.   

Option Analysis

❌ Kidney:
Incorrect: Red infarcts tend to develop in loosely organized organs with multiple blood supplies (e.g., liver, lungs). In contrast, the kidneys are supplied by a single blood vessel, the renal artery. As a result, a pale infarct will more likely be seen in the kidneys.  
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: Red infarcts tend to develop in loosely organized organs with multiple blood supplies (e.g., liver, lungs). In contrast, the spleen is supplied by a single blood supply, the splenic artery. As a result, the spleen will more likely exhibit a pale infarct pattern.  
✅ Lungs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Heart:
Incorrect: Blood supply to the heart tissue is provided almost exclusively by the coronary arteries. As a result, the heart will more likely have a pale infarct. In contrast, loosely organized organs with multiple blood supplies (e.g., liver, lungs) can develop red infarcts, which occur when blood from the non-occluded vessel(s) can reenter the infarcted region.  
❌ Retina:
Incorrect: Blood supply to the retina is provided almost exclusively by the central retinal artery. As a result, the retina will more likely have a pale infarct. In contrast, loosely organized organs with dual blood supplies (e.g., liver, lungs) can develop red infarcts, which occur when blood from the non-occluded vessel(s) can reenter the infarcted region.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 2-year history of frequent substernal chest pain. His symptoms are worse at night and after large meals. The patient has also noticed recurrent reflux of gastric contents into his throat and mouth. The patient does not experience dysphagia, and has had any weight loss. The patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history and drinks approximately 3-4 beers per day. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Examination shows no abnormalities. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsies taken at the lower esophageal sphincter (shown below). Biopsy results from the lower esophagus showed a nonciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following is true regarding these changes seen in the lower esophagus?

choices.text: These changes are characterized by abnormal and uncontrolled cellular growth
Nuclear pleomorphism is expected at this stage
These changes are benign with no malignant potential
These changes can progress to carcinoma

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is characterized by recurrent symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation, as seen in this patient. Barrett esophagus is a complication of chronic GERD, which can be visualized on endoscopy (seen in this patient). A biopsy will show metaplasia with replacement of the normal non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus with non-ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (normally in the small intestine), which can better withstand acid exposure.  

Metaplasia is a physiological process in which the body handles a stressor. When certain types of cells are unable to handle a stressor, stem cells produce new types of cells that are better able to handle this stress.  

Metaplasia can be reversible with removal of the stressor. However, if the stressor persists, metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and carcinoma.    

Option Analysis

❌ These changes are irreversible  :
Incorrect: This patient has Barett esophagus, which is metaplasia characterized by the conversion of the non-keratinized squamous epithelium to nonciliated columnar epithelium. Metaplasia is reversible if the stressor is removed.  
❌ These changes are characterized by abnormal and uncontrolled cellular growth  :
Incorrect: Barett esophagus is metaplasia, and in metaplasia, there is no abnormal or uncontrolled cellular growth.
❌ Nuclear pleomorphism is expected at this stage  :
Incorrect: Nuclear pleomorphism is seen in dysplasia and carcinoma, but not in metaplasia.  
❌ These changes are benign with no malignant potential  :
Incorrect: Although metaplasia (e.g., Barrett esophagus) are reversible physiologic changes, it can progress to dysplasia and neoplasia if the stressor was not removed.  
✅ These changes can progress to carcinoma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the clinic due to pain and paresthesia in his right hand. He currently works as a mechanic. Examination shows decreased muscle bulk of the right thenar eminence. A nerve conduction study confirms diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following helps explain the appearance of the thenar eminence?

choices.text: Decreased release of SMACs from the mitochondrial membrane.
Increased cell membrane rupture and inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with carpal tunnel syndrome, which is due to compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel. This leads to decreased nerve supply (denervation) to the muscles supplied by the nerve  (i.e., the muscles of the thenar eminence), causing atrophy of the thenar eminence as seen in this patient.    

Atrophy is the process of decreasing tissue mass by decreasing either the cell size or the number of cells. Important causes of atrophy include disuse, denervation, nutritional deficiency, and lack of hormone stimulation.  

First of all, decreased cell number in atrophy is caused by apoptosis, which is a programmed cell death that is not followed by inflammation (unlike necrosis).  

On the other hand, decreased cell size is achieved by the activation of an important method called the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, where parts of the cytoskeleton are tagged by ubiquitin and subsequently degraded by proteasomes. Additionally, ubiquitin tags organelles within the cell too. When this happens, a vacuole forms around the ubiquitinated organelle and a lysosomal vesicle fuses with the vacuole, releasing digestive enzymes into the vacuole and degrading the organelle. Both of these processes cause a decrease in cell size.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased expression of Bcl-2:
Incorrect: Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein. It stabilizes the mitochondrial membrane to prevent leakage of cytochrome C. One method of atrophy is decreasing cell number by apoptosis, which would be inhibited by increasing the expression of Bcl-2.
❌ Absence of primordial tissue  :
Incorrect: The absence of primordial tissue leads to agenesis, which is an absent organ due to failure during embryologic development.  
❌ Decreased release of SMACs from the mitochondrial membrane.  :
Incorrect: SMACs (second mitochondrial activator of caspases) are released from the mitochondrial membrane and bind to and inactivate proteins that normally inhibit apoptosis. One method of atrophy is decreasing cell numbers by apoptosis, which is aided by increasing the release of SMACs.
❌ Increased cell membrane rupture and inflammation  :
Incorrect: Cell membrane rupture and resulting inflammation occur in necrosis, not atrophy.
✅ Increased degradation of ubiquitin-tagged proteins  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the clinic with weight gain, facial swelling, and muscle weakness. Physical examination shows marked central obesity with thinning of the extremities and abundant purple striae covering the abdomen. Serum laboratory studies show glucose is 205 mg/dL, cortisol is 80 ug/dL, and an elevated ACTH. ACTH levels are decreased after the administration of a high dose of dexamethasone. Head CT scan reveals an adenoma in the pituitary gland and the patient was diagnosed with ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma. The elevated levels of ACTH will cause which of the following changes in the adrenal glands?
questions.solution:
Hyperplasia and hypertrophy are two adaptive mechanisms the body uses when there is increased stress on a tissue or an organ.    

Hyperplasia is an increase in cell number within a tissue due to cell proliferation that may lead to the gross enlargement of an organ. In order for hyperplasia to occur, the tissue must contain stem cells that are able to divide and differentiate. This includes the gastrointestinal tract, the liver, the skin, and the bone marrow, among other tissues. On the other hand, tissues that lack stem cells (also known as permanent tissues) cannot undergo hyperplasia. This includes neurons, the adult skeletal muscle, and cardiac tissue.
 

Hyperplasia can result from both physiological and pathological stresses on certain tissues. In addition, hyperplasia can be divided into 2 categories: compensatory hyperplasia and regulatory hyperplasia. Compensatory hyperplasia occurs in tissues that are able to regenerate like the liver and the skin, while regulatory hyperplasia occurs in tissues that are regulated by hormones like the adrenal glands, the thyroid glands, and others.  

Hyperplasia is usually tightly regulated and controlled cellular growth. However, in some cases where the stress is pathological, the increased cellular division can lead to a mutation in one of the dividing cells, which leads to the progression of hyperplasia to dysplasia, where the cells are abnormal and they divide uncontrollably. Dysplasia can then progress to neoplasia and cancer. One important example is endometrial hyperplasia, which occurs in the state of increased estrogen stimulation to the endometrial lining. In the case of prolonged exposure to high levels of estrogen, endometrial hyperplasia can progress to dysplasia and carcinoma.  

Hypertrophy, on the other hand, is an increase in cell size in response to increased stress. Organs that are incapable of hyperplasia (i.e. permanent tissues) respond to increased stress by hypertrophy only, while organs that are capable of hyperplasia usually have both hyperplasia and hypertrophy together when exposed to increased stress. Like hyperplasia, hypertrophy can develop due to a physiological or pathological stressor; however, unlike hyperplasia, hypertrophy does not carry an increased risk of dysplasia and carcinoma.  


Option Analysis

❌ Atrophy:
Incorrect: Atrophy is a decrease in the function of a tissue due to decreased size or number of cells. It commonly occurs due to denervation of tissue, poor nutrition, and disuse.  This can be seen in the adrenal glands in patients taking exogenous steroids; the pituitary and hypothalamus stop signaling the adrenals to produce cortisol, resulting in adrenal tissue atrophy.  
✅ Hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dysplasia:
Incorrect: Dysplasia is uncontrolled cellular growth and replication due to a mutation. Although hyperplasia can develop into dysplasia, in some cases, this is quite rare to happen in the adrenal glands in patients with Cushing disease.  
❌ Hypoplasia:
Incorrect: Hypoplasia is the underdevelopment of an organ or tissue. It is normally congenital and is less severe than aplasia. An example is streak ovaries in Turner syndrome.  
❌ Neoplasia:
Incorrect: Neoplasia is an uncontrolled, monoclonal proliferation of cells. In Cushing disease, the neoplasm is in the pituitary gland, not the adrenal gland.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes a pulmonary lymph node biopsy to evaluate chronic cough with the histologic finding demonstrated below. Which of the following chemical mediators is responsible for developing the observed microscopic lesion?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
The development of granulomas is mediated by both chemical and immunological responses of macrophages and T-helper one cells. Following exposure to an antigen, an antigen-presenting cell triggers a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, wherein macrophages housing the antigen present to naive CD4 T-helper cells. Macrophages then secrete IL-12, differentiating the CD4 cells into T-helper 1 cells. The T-helper one cells then migrate to the site of inflammation, where they release interferon-gamma and activate other macrophages. As more macrophages become activated, they recruit even more macrophages and neutrophils via the release of TNF-alpha. These cells surround the foreign material and form epithelioid histiocytes, multinucleated Langhans giant cells, and granulomas.  

Option Analysis

✅ TNF-alpha :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Leukotriene C4:
Incorrect: Leukotriene C4 is an endogenous mediator that increases vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation. It is not directly involved in granuloma formation.
❌ PGE2 :
Incorrect: Prostaglandins are primarily responsible for the effects of vasodilation, pain, and fever. They are produced by mast cells and leukocytes. 
❌ IL-1:
Incorrect: IL-1, an interleukin, is primarily an endogenous pyrogen. It is not directly involved in granulomatous formation. 
❌ Hepcidin:
Incorrect: Hepcidin is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant. It is not directly involved in granulomatous formation.

questions.text: An experiment is conducted by a scientist on a cell line in a laboratory. A protein molecule is introduced into the tissue culture dish containing the cell line that binds to a transmembrane protein. As a result, the affected cell undergoes membrane blebbing and pyknosis as shown below. Which of the following protein molecules are most likely introduced into the culture?
questions.solution:
In the vignette, a molecule is introduced that triggers the process of apoptosis (as hinted by formation of membrane blebs and pyknosis). Of the options listed, only Fas-ligand (FasL) is a molecule that binds to Fas, a transmembrane protein, to trigger apoptosis via an extrinsic pathway. It is similar to TNF-alpha in that the latter also binds to its receptor to initiate apoptosis. It is called ligand-receptor interaction.  

When these molecules bind to their receptors, a cascade of events takes place which results in the activation of initiator caspases, which in turn, trigger executioner caspases. These caspases break down cellular structures like the nucleus, organelles, and cytoskeleton. This results in pyknosis and the formation of blebs in the membrane. These blebs are structurally weak, so they break off from the membrane to form apoptotic bodies, which are engulfed by the macrophages.  



Option Analysis

❌ Perforin:
Incorrect: Perforin is involved in the apoptosis pathway which is mediated by killer CD8+ T cells. Perforin acts by damaging the cell membrane, not by binding to a transmembrane receptor.
❌ Granzyme B  :
Incorrect: Granzyme B is involved in the apoptosis pathway which is mediated by killer CD8+ T cells. It requires perforin to form pores in the target cells so that granzyme B is transferred where it activates caspases. Granzyme B does not bind to a transmembrane receptor.  
✅ Fas-ligand (FasL)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bcl-2  :
Incorrect: Bcl-2 is an intracellular anti-apoptotic molecule that prevents apoptosis via the mitochondrial pathway by preventing the release of cytochrome C. It is not pro-apoptotic and does not bind to a transmembrane receptor.  
❌ Interleukin 2 (IL-2)  :
Incorrect: A decrease in growth factors (e.g. IL-2 for proliferating immune cells) can lead to the induction of the intrinsic apoptosis pathway. In the question stem, a molecule is introduced to induce apoptosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of a new painless lump in her left breast that she noticed yesterday. She has no other symptoms. Her past medical history includes a recent left breast biopsy for a lesion found on screening mammography, which turned out to be benign. The patient’s sibling was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma two years ago. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 148/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a painless, irregularly-shaped fluctuant mass, with mild erythema and bruising of the overlying skin. The mammogram is shown below. Which of the following pathological features is expected to be present?  


Case courtesy of Dr Chris O'Donnell at Radiopaedia

choices.text: Malignant cells with invasion of dermal lymphatics
Non-invasive neoplastic cells in ductal lumen with microcalcifications

questions.solution:
This patient with painless irregularly-shaped fluctuant mass, with mild erythema and bruising of the overlying breast shortly after undergoing breast biopsy is highly indicative of fat necrosis of the breast.  

Fat necrosis is a type of necrosis that occurs due to fatty organ trauma which leads to rupture of the adipose cell membranes, leading to leakage of fatty acids. These fatty acids may combine with calcium, leading to dystrophic calcification that can be seen on mammography (as in this patient).    

Patients may present with a painless (or sometimes painful) mass, with mild bruising, erythema, or dimpling of the overlying skin. It is sometimes confused for malignancy on physical examination or radiologic studies. However, this is a benign condition that will resolve, or may require drainage of large oil cysts (collections of liquefied fat).  

Option Analysis

❌ Acini and stromal fibrosis:
Incorrect: This finding is associated with sclerosing adenosis, which is a subtype of fibrocystic changes in the breast. There is a slight increase in cancer risk with these changes. This commonly presents with bilateral and multifocal premenstrual breast pain or lumps.  
✅ Fat necrosis with dystrophic calcification  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malignant cells with invasion of dermal lymphatics  :
Incorrect: Inflammatory carcinoma involves invasion of the dermal lymphatics. It usually presents with warmth, swelling, erythema, and an orange peel-like appearance (peau d’orange). There is usually no palpable mass.  
❌ Abscess formation with liquefactive necrosis  :
Incorrect: A breast abscess would be felt as a fluctuant mass. However, they progress from underlying mastitis. Patients would present with a swollen, firm, tender, and erythematous breast which usually occurs during breast-feeding. Such patients mostly have flu-like symptoms, malaise, fever, and chills, which are not present here.  
❌ Non-invasive neoplastic cells in ductal lumen with microcalcifications:
Incorrect: This finding indicates ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Although calcifications are present on this mammogram, this is highly unlikely based on the fact that she has already undergone breast-cancer screening.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of the cardinal signs of inflammation in rat models. The researcher is particularly interested in understanding the mechanism resulting in abnormal enlargement and edema formation within a rat's limb after subjecting them to a painful stimulus. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely to be directly responsible for the swelling seen in the limb?
questions.solution:
This researcher studies the cardinal sign of inflammation referred to as “tumor” or swelling. Swelling is primarily mediated by leukotrienes (along with histamine), eicosanoid inflammatory mediators secreted by mast cells, and leukocytes that increase vascular permeability, chemotaxis, and leukocyte adhesion, and activation. 

The cardinal signs of inflammation were coined by Celsus's Roman encyclopedist more than 2000 years ago. They included heat (“calor”), redness (“rubor”), swelling (“tumor”), pain (“dolor”), and loss of function (“functio laesa”) secondary to the effects of these signs. Multiple chemical mediators are responsible for these features of inflammation and are outlined in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Leukotrienes :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Prostaglandins :
Incorrect: Prostaglandins are primarily responsible for the effects of vasodilation, pain, and fever. They are produced by mast cells and leukocytes.   
❌ Chemokines:
Incorrect: Chemokines, produced by leukocytes and activated macrophages, result in chemotaxis (movement of cells towards the site of inflammation) and leukocyte activation.   
❌ Cytokines :
Incorrect: Cytokines, produced by macrophages, endothelial cells, and mast cells, mediate endothelial activation. These molecules are primarily responsible for fever, metabolic derangements, and shock.   
❌ Complement :
Incorrect: Complement, produced in the liver and circulating in plasma, serves several functions, including leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), and vasodilation via mast cell stimulation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of the acute phase reactants in rat models. The researcher injects a viral protein into a rat, results in a core temperature change from 98.6 F° (37 C°) to 101.2 F° (38.4 C°). Which of the following substances is expected to be downregulated after serological testing?
questions.solution:
Acute phase reactants are plasma proteins produced by the liver that may increase several thousand-fold in response to an inflammatory stimulus. They are largely produced to aid in recognizing microbial cell walls, sequestration of iron, and act as opsonins to fix complement.    

Acute phase reactants that are upregulated during periods of acute inflammation include ferritin, fibrinogen, serum amyloid A, hepcidin, and C-reactive protein. In contrast, other molecules are down-regulated during periods of acute inflammation, including albumin and transferrin. Albumin becomes down-regulated as a protective mechanism to conserve bodily amino acids to synthesize upregulated acute phase reactants. In contrast, macrophages internalize transferrin to sequester iron and inhibit microbial iron scavenging.   

Option Analysis

✅ Albumin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: C-reactive protein is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant.   
❌ Hepcidin:
Incorrect: Hepcidin is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant. Elevated serum levels of hepcidin in chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis) can result in anemia of chronic disease since hepcidin causes iron to be retained within cells of the reticuloendothelial system.  
❌ Fibrinogen:
Incorrect: Fibrinogen is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant.   
❌ Serum amyloid A:
Incorrect: Serum amyloid A (AA) is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant. The buildup of AA can occur in the organs of patients with chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis), ultimately resulting in amyloidosis.

questions.text: A researcher is writing a review article on the types of cell deaths. Which of the following is an example of apoptosis?

choices.text: Digital cell death in a patient with severe peripheral arterial disease
Myocardial cell death secondary to myocardial infarction
Cell death secondary to free radical injury
Cellular breakdown between the digits to avoid webbing during fetal development
Neuronal cell death secondary to ischemic stroke

questions.solution:
Apoptosis is simply defined as programmed cell death, which occurs, for the most part, as a normal and controlled part of an organism's growth or development. It is triggered by specific DNA sequences that are a sensitive indicator of apoptosis. On the other hand, necrosis is defined as the death of the cells in an organ or tissue due to disease, injury, or failure of the blood supply.  

Apoptosis occurs via two (intrinsic and extrinsic) pathways, both of which result in activation of caspases that cause nuclear fragmentation and cytoskeletal dispersion, forming small apoptotic bodies that are engulfed by macrophages. In contrast, when necrosis occurs, it is usually secondary to exogenous injury that causes plasma membrane damage, enzymatic degradation, protein denaturation, and intracellular components leak. This mounts a local inflammatory response (unlike apoptosis).  

Examples of apoptosis include tissue remodeling during embryogenesis (e.g. cells in the digital webs undergo apoptosis and which allows us to form individual digits) and old skin cells that routinely get replaced by new skin cells.

Option Analysis

❌ Digital cell death in a patient with severe peripheral arterial disease  :
Incorrect: Digital cell death (cell death of the digits i.e., toes, fingers) in a patient with severe peripheral arterial disease occurs secondary to severe hypoxia that denatures the enzymes and inhibits proteolysis, leading to cellular injury and necrosis. It is classified as coagulative necrosis.  
❌ Myocardial cell death secondary to myocardial infarction  :
Incorrect: Myocardial cell death secondary to myocardial infarction secondary to severe hypoxia that denatures the enzymes and inhibits proteolysis, leading to cellular injury and necrosis. It is also classified as coagulative necrosis.  
❌ Cell death secondary to free radical injury  :
Incorrect: Free radicals damage cells by causing protein modification, lipid peroxidation, and DNA breakage that leads to necrosis. It is usually seen in patients with radiation exposure, during metabolism of certain drugs in phase I, redox reactions, and in inflammatory states.  
✅ Cellular breakdown between the digits to avoid webbing during fetal development:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neuronal cell death secondary to ischemic stroke  :
Incorrect: Neuronal cell death secondary to ischemic stroke occurs secondary to severe hypoxia that denatures the enzymes and inhibits proteolysis, leading to cellular injury. Lysosomal enzymes are released that cause cystic spaces and cavitation, causing liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text:
A pre-medical student presents to their local urgent care clinic after a slip and fall on the hard pavement (injury of the hand documented below). While the patient is having their hand irrigated, they ask the physician what she would expect to see if she examined the area of injury under a microscope. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis
Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis
Mononuclear infiltration with lymphocytes and plasma cells
Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen

questions.solution:
Acute inflammation is a complex process that is histologically characterized by the presence of localized edema and neutrophils. In general, acute inflammation is defined as an early or transient response to injury and infection and represents the major functions of the innate immune system. Acute inflammation gets divided into three major components: dilation of small vessels, increased permeability of the microvasculature, and emigration and activation of leukocytes from the microcirculation to their accumulation in the focus of injury.  

When a stimulus (foreign body, bacteria) enters the body, local phagocytes recognize pathogens via Toll-like receptors (TLRS) and attempt to eliminate the foreign agent while simultaneously releasing chemical mediators to dilate small blood vessels and recruit additional leukocytes to the site of injury. Over time, several outcomes may occur at the site of injury. Most commonly, resolution and healing occur (mediated by IL-10 and TGF-β).  Sometimes persistent acute inflammation may occur, resulting in abscess formation (mediated by IL-8), chronic inflammation (antigen presentation by macrophages and other APCs activation of CD4+ Th cells), and scarring.  

Option Analysis

✅ Localized edema and neutrophils:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis:
Incorrect: Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis characterize the caseating granulomatous disease, which is often observed with infectious fungal agents or tuberculosis.   
❌ Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis:
Incorrect: Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis characterize a non-caseating granulomatous disease, which is often observed with autoimmune conditions such as sarcoidosis.   
❌ Mononuclear infiltration with lymphocytes and plasma cells:
Incorrect: Mononuclear infiltration with lymphocytes and plasma cells describes the histologic findings associated with chronic, not acute, inflammation.   
❌ Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen:
Incorrect: Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen are found in keloids (abnormal scar formation).

questions.text: An immunologist is performing gene silencing experiments to understand the process of leukocyte extravasation during episodes of acute inflammation. The researcher silences a leukocyte gene and finds that leukocytes can no longer travel between endothelial cells and exit the blood vessel. Which of the following proteins is most likely aberrant in this experiment?
questions.solution:
The process of leukocyte extravasation–where white blood cells move towards a site of injury from the vasculature–is a complex process mediated by both leukocyte and endothelial factors. The process is divided into four steps: margination and rolling, adhesion, diapedesis, and migration.    

During margination and rolling, blood flow slows in post-capillary venules, and cells marginate from the center of the flow to the periphery. Next, molecules on the surface of endothelial cells called selectins bind  Sialyl Lewisx protein on the surface of leukocytes allowing for rolling along the vessel wall. During adhesion, two molecules called ICAM and CAM are upregulated on the endothelium via TNF and IL-1, whereas integrins are upregulated on leukocytes. Tight binding between integrins and CAM proteins results in firm adhesion of leukocytes to the vessel wall. During diapedesis, leukocytes physically cross between endothelial cells via PECAM-1, where they further migrate to the site of injury via chemotaxis.  



Option Analysis

✅ PECAM-1:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ ICAM-1:
Incorrect: ICAM-1 is an endothelial protein responsible for tight adhesion. The stem mentioned above describes the process of diapedesis (passage of blood cells through the intact walls of the capillaries).   
❌ Sialyl Lewisx :
Incorrect: Sialyl Lewis is a leukocyte-related membrane protein responsible for margination and rolling. This protein is deficient in leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2.   
❌ Leukotriene C4:
Incorrect:  Leukotriene C4 is an endogenous mediator that increases vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation. It is not directly responsible for diapedesis (passage of blood cells through the intact walls of the capillaries).   
❌ IL-1:
Incorrect: IL-1, an interleukin, is primarily an endogenous pyrogen. It is not directly involved in diapedesis (passage of blood cells through the intact walls of the capillaries).

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma following a long-standing infection with hepatitis C. Following the appointment, a medical student asks the physician why this happened, and the physician begins to explain the process of chronic inflammation. The student then asks what the cells in his liver would likely look like under a microscope. Which would most likely be seen on pathological examination in chronic inflammation?

choices.text: Mononuclear infiltration with lymphocytes and plasma cells
Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis
Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis
Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen

questions.solution:
Chronic inflammation refers to a delayed but more specific form of adaptive immunity. Histologically, this form of inflammation is characterized by lymphocytes and plasma cells in tissue.    

Chronic inflammation includes multiple stimuli including persistent infections (most common cause), autoimmune disease, foreign material, and some malignancies. Interactions between macrophages and T-lymphocytes predominantly drive this form of inflammation. Specific mediators include CD4+ T cells that secrete cytokines that promote inflammation via two pathways:  

  •  Th1 cells secrete IFN-γ, resulting in the macrophage classical activation pathway (proinflammatory) 
  •  Th2 cells secrete IL-4 and IL-13 and promote alternative macrophage activation (repair and anti-Inflammatory pathway)  
Outcomes of chronic inflammation are multiple and include malignant transformation, scarring, and amyloidosis. The outcome often depends on the instigator of inflammation (e.g. chronic hepatitis C infection and malignant transformation).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Mononuclear infiltration with lymphocytes and plasma cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis:
Incorrect: Multinucleated giant cells with central necrosis characterize the caseating granulomatous disease, which is often observed with infectious fungal agents or tuberculosis.   
❌ Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis:
Incorrect: Multinucleated giant cells without central necrosis characterize the non-caseating granulomatous disease, which is often observed with autoimmune conditions such as sarcoidosis.   
❌ Localized edema and neutrophils:
Incorrect: Localized edema and neutrophils describes the histologic findings associated with acute, not chronic, inflammation.   
❌ Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen:
Incorrect: Bands of disorganized type I and III collagen are found in keloids (abnormal scar formation).

questions.text: An investigator is studying the formation of digits in chick embryos. In early embryogenesis, some tissue specimens show cells with nuclear shrinkage and fragmentation, chromatin condensation, and membrane blebbing. Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Entry of granzyme B into the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Apoptosis is programmed cell death. Activation of apoptosis can occur via the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway or extrinsic (death receptor pathway).  

For the intrinsic pathway, a signal (e.g. removal of a regulating factor, radiation, toxins, hypoxia) leads to the activation of BAX and BAK, which then pierce holes in the mitochondrial membrane, allowing the cytochrome C to exit the mitochondria. Cytochrome C then binds to Apaf-1 and ATP to form an apoptosome that cleaves pro-caspase 9 to caspase 9, activating the caspase cascade that leads to apoptosis. An example of the intrinsic pathway is the formation of digits during embryogenesis when the hands and feet contain excess tissue between the soon-to-be digits that must undergo apoptosis.  


In contrast, the extrinsic pathway is triggered when there is a ligand-receptor or immune cell (CD8) interaction. In the former,  Fas-ligand (FasL) is a molecule that binds to Fas, a transmembrane protein, to trigger apoptosis. It is similar to TNF-alpha in that it also binds to its transmembrane receptor to initiate apoptosis. On the other hand, when CD8+ T cell interacts with the cell that needs to undergo apoptosis, it releases perforin and granzyme B which activate caspases.  


Each pathway ultimately leads to the activation cascade of caspase proteins. These caspase proteins cleave integral proteins and degrade cellular components. The cell ultimately loses its structure, resulting in membrane blebbing, which forms apoptotic bodies that undergo phagocytosis. Apoptotic cells appear densely eosinophilic, with a basophilic nucleus that is condensed (pyknosis) and fragmented (karyorrhexis).  

Option Analysis

❌ Fas ligand binding to Fas (CD95):
Incorrect: FasL binds to Fas in the extrinsic (death receptor) pathway, not the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway.  
❌ Entry of granzyme B into the cytoplasm:
Incorrect: Cytotoxic T cells can release granzyme B and perforin into cells to activate apoptosis via an extrinsic pathway. This is not a part of the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway.  
✅ Activation of BAX and BAK  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased expression of Bcl-2  :
Incorrect: Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein. It stabilizes the mitochondrial membrane to prevent the leakage of cytochrome C, which is a part of the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway.  
❌ TNF-ɑ binding to death receptor  :
Incorrect: TNF-ɑ binding to a death receptor is a part of the extrinsic (death receptor) pathway, not the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and multiple cerebrovascular accidents is found unresponsive in her apartment. Her pharmacy records showed that she did not refill her medications for the past month. On initial forensic analysis, it is suspected that she died from a stroke nearly 2 weeks ago. The family wants to determine the cause and agrees to an autopsy. If she did die from an ischemic stroke 2 weeks ago, which of the following findings are most likely to be seen on histopathology of the affected area of the brain?

choices.text: Cellular debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages

questions.solution:
This deceased patient with suspicion of death from an ischemic stroke almost 2 weeks ago will most likely have a formation of cystic cavitation in the affected area as it will be in the late stage of liquefactive necrosis.  

Necrosis is an inflammatory process by which cell injury results in enzymatic degradation of cellular contents, lysis of cells, and protein denaturation. In the central nervous system (CNS), it starts with neuronal cytoplasmic eosinophilia on day 1 of injury. Then chromatin condenses and eventually, the nucleus degenerates. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes are among the first cells seen at the site of injury. Around day 3, microglial cells infiltrate and start ingesting cellular debris, resulting in a "foamy" macrophage appearance. The lysosomal enzymes completely destroy the damaged cells and debris, thereby liquefying the dead tissue and forming a soft, cystic mass. Histologically, the cystic space contains cellular debris and macrophages. Cavitation can be seen 12 days after injury. Additionally, a cyst wall can form.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased binding of acidophilic dyes  :
Incorrect: Increased binding of acidophilic dyes occurs in coagulative necrosis due to increased binding of eosin to denatured intracytoplasmic proteins, which is seen in ischemic injuries to most tissue except the brain.  
❌ Fat saponification:
Incorrect: Fat saponification is usually seen in fat necrosis which occurs due to fatty organ trauma which leads to rupture of the adipose cell membranes, leading to leakage of fatty acids. These fatty acids may saponify with calcium to form deposits.  
✅ Cystic cavitation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cellular debris and neutrophils:
Incorrect: Cellular debris and neutrophils are usually seen at the site of bacterial infections. Neutrophilic hydrolysis can cause liquefactive necrosis, but focal bacterial infection is not expected to be the cause of death for this patient.  
❌ Cellular debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages  :
Incorrect: Granulomas are described as a histopathology finding of cellular debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages. It is usually seen in mycobacterial or fungal infections.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of the acute mediators of inflammation in rat models. The researcher injects a bacterial substance into a rat resulting in a core temperature change from 98.6 F° (37 C°) to 101.2 F° (38.4 C°). Which of the following is the most likely mediator of this acute change in homeostasis?
questions.solution:
Pyrogens are molecules responsible for causing fevers and are characterized as either external or internal. One of the well-established pyrogens is the Gram-negative cell wall component of bacteria called lipopolysaccharide (LPS).    

Fever is an elevation of body temperature from baseline–usually by 1° to 4°C–and several mediators are involved in this process. Typically, external pyrogens from infectious agents (e.g. LPS) trigger leukocytes to release cytokines such as IL-1 and TNF (endogenous pyrogens) that increase the activity of cyclooxygenases that ultimately convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. In the hypothalamus, prostaglandins (specifically PGE2) increase the temperature setpoint, resulting in fever. The evolutionary and biochemical protective effects of fever are still being studied.   

Option Analysis

✅ Lipopolysaccharide :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Leukotriene C4:
Incorrect:  Leukotriene C4 is an endogenous mediator that increases vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation.   
❌ Serum amyloid A :
Incorrect: Serum amyloid A is an acute phase reactant that can result in amyloidosis–it is not considered a pyrogen.   
❌ Histamine:
Incorrect: Histamine is a crucial mediator of acute inflammation; however, it is not considered a pyrogen. Histamine is responsible mainly for vasodilation, vascular permeability, and endothelial activation.   
❌ Cyclooxygenase inhibitor :
Incorrect: Cyclooxygenase inhibitors, such as aspirin or ibuprofen, are anti-pyrogens. Thus, administration of one of these compounds would decrease fever, not induce it.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of inflammation involving atherosclerotic plaques in the coronary arteries that predispose to thrombosis and subsequent infarction. The researcher postulates that an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate predisposes patients to an increased risk of myocardial infarction. Which of the following chemical mediators is most directly responsible for measuring this assay?
questions.solution:
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a commercially used inflammatory assay that measures the distance that red blood cells in anticoagulated blood fall in a vertical tube after one hour. Normally, red blood cells remain separated from one another via negative charges. With acute inflammation, fibrinogen levels (an acute phase reactant) rise, resulting in the binding of this protein to red blood cells, reducing their charge. With a reduced red blood cell charge, the cells subsequently aggregate together (rouleaux formations), causing them to fall to the bottom of the tube more rapidly at unit gravity than individual red cells. An ESR will typically start to rise within 24-48 hours of acute inflammation, but in contrast to C-reactive protein, the ESR is a less sensitive marker of acute inflammation. Conditions where the ESR is elevated or depressed, are detailed in the chart below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fibrinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Leukotriene C4:
Incorrect:  Leukotriene C4 is an endogenous mediator that increases vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation. 
❌ Serum amyloid A:
Incorrect: Serum amyloid A is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant; however, it is not directly correlated with the measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate.   
❌ Histamine:
Incorrect: Histamine is a key mediator of acute inflammation; however, it is not considered when measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate.  
❌ C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: C-reactive protein is a positive (upregulated) acute phase reactant. It is not directly correlated with the measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes a pulmonary lymph node biopsy to evaluate chronic cough with the histologic finding demonstrated below. Which of the following pathological processes likely preceded the development of this histologic finding?


 Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: CD4+ helper T-cell response to unknown antigen
Acute inflammation surrounding a foreign body

questions.solution:
The above histologic image shows a caseating granuloma (note the area of central necrosis, where no nucleoli can be seen). Of the answer choices listed, only prior infection with tuberculosis is known to induce the formation of caseating granulomas.    

Granulomatous inflammation, a subtype of chronic inflammation, refers to an immune response where the body attempts to isolate foreign substances that it is otherwise unable to eliminate. Histologically, it is characterized by epithelioid histiocytes (macrophages with abundant pink cytoplasm) surrounded by giant cells and a rim of lymphocytes. Granulomatous inflammation gets classified into caseating and non-caseating forms (where an area of central necrosis histologically characterizes the latter). In general, non-caseating granulomas are more commonly due to autoimmune disease, whereas caseating granulomas arise from underlying infectious etiologies. The table below outlines diseases that encompass both caseating and noncaseating forms.  



Option Analysis

✅ Infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Beryllium exposure :
Incorrect:  Beryllium, an alkaline earth metal, can cause chronic restrictive lung disease. Exposure to this element results in non-caseating granulomatous disease.  


Noncaseating granuloma Reproduced from: Flikr
❌ Silica exposure:
Incorrect: Chronic silica exposure is implicated in the development of non-caseating granulomatous disease.


 Noncaseating granuloma Reproduced from: Flikr
❌ CD4+ helper T-cell response to unknown antigen:
Incorrect: This describes the proposed mechanism of sarcoidosis, a non-caseating granulomatous disease.


Noncaseating granuloma Reproduced from: Flikr
❌ Acute inflammation surrounding a foreign body:
Incorrect: In general, foreign bodies develop non-caseating granulomas; however, the pathological image obtained from the patient demonstrates a caseating granuloma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual comes to the physician due to low-grade fever and skin discoloration. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy three days ago. The surgery was complicated by an episode of acute hemorrhaging when an artery was inadvertently ligated, and the patient was given two units of blood. The patient’s postoperative period was normal without any complications, and the patient was discharged yesterday. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 120/80, and pulse is 70/minute. On physical examination, the physician notices skin pallor and mild jaundice in the patient’s eyes. The patient’s incisions are healing well without any discharge, bleeding, or erythema. The abdomen is soft with appropriate tenderness in the area of the incision. Both legs are symmetrical in circumference with no signs of swelling, warmth, or tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with mild jaundice and low-grade fever three days after the patient had an operation and was given blood transfusion. One of the important differential diagnoses that should be suspected is a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction. 

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are a complication of blood transfusions that result from antibodies that form against minor RBC antigens (e.g. Rh) transfused to patients. Before the transfusion, the titers of these antibodies are usually very low. However, after exposure to the antigens on transfused RBCs, more antibodies start forming, and within days, hemolysis occurs. This hemolysis mostly occurs extravascularly and is typically much more mild than acute hemolytic reactions (which are mostly due to ABO incompatibility).  

Patients with delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction typically present between 24 hours and one month of a transfusion with low-grade fevers and jaundice. However, many patients are usually asymptomatic. The serum bilirubin will be mildly elevated, and the patient's hemoglobin might decrease. Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are rarely serious, and management is usually supportive.  

Option Analysis

✅ Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical site infection :
Incorrect: Although surgical site infections can lead to fever post-operatively, this complication is unlikely to be the cause in this patient as their incisions are without any pain, discharge, or erythema. 
❌ Postcholecystectomy syndrome:
Incorrect: Postcholecystectomy syndrome (PCS) is defined as the persistence of biliary colic (right upper quadrant pain) along with other gastrointestinal symptoms after cholecystectomy. The condition can occur early after the operation or years later. However, this patient is experiencing mild fever and jaundice without biliary colic, making PCS an unlikely diagnosis.
❌ Deep venous thrombosis:
